ul.li: Use the limits \ds \lim_{\theta\to 0} \dfrac{\sin \theta}{\theta} = 1 and \ds \lim_{\theta\to 0} \dfrac{\cos\theta -1}{\theta} = 0 to aid the computation of the derivative of sine and cosine
Apply the derivative rules of Section 2.3 to all six trigonometric functions

subsubsection.title: Special Trig Limits
subsubsection.p: There are two limits of trigonometric functions that we will take advantage of in Section 2.4.

example.statement: Use the limits above to show that \dfrac{d}{dx}\left[\sin x\right] = \cos x.
Find the derivative of f(x) = \cos x.

Find the derivatives of the following functions using the rules from \S2.3 and the definition of the remaining four functions:
\tan x
\cot x
\sec x
\csc x
Find f'(x), if f(x) = x^3\cos x.
Find the equation of the tangent line to the curve y = 2\sin x - \cos x at the point (0,-1).
Find \ds \lim_{x\to 0} \dfrac{\sin 3x}{5x}.
Find the limit: \ds \lim_{t\to 0} \dfrac{\tan 6t}{\sin 2t}
Find the limit: \ds \lim_{x\to 0} \dfrac{\sin x}{\sin \pi x}
Find the limit: \ds \lim_{x\to 0} \dfrac{\sin 3x}{5x^3 - 4x}
For what values of x does f(x) = \dfrac{\cos x}{1-\sin x} have a horizontal tangent?

An object at the end of a vertical spring is stretched 5 cm beyond its resting position, and released at time t = 0. Its position at time t is given by s(t) = 5\sin t.
Find the velocity and acceleration at time t
At what time(s) is the velocity of the object 0? What about the acceleration?
Differentiate y = u(a\cos u + b\cot u), where a,b are constants.
Differentiate y = x^2\sin x\tan x
Find the derivative of y = \dfrac{t\sin t}{1+t}
Find the 101st derivative of f(x) = 2\cos x.
Find the 99th derivative of f(x) = \sin x
Find the equation of the tangent line to the curve y = x+\tan x at the point (\pi,\pi). Then, find the equation of the normal line through that point.
Suppose f(\pi/3) = 4, and f'(\pi/3) = -2. Let g(x) = f(x)\sin x and h(x) = \dfrac{\cos x}{f(x)}. Find g'(\pi/3) and h'(\pi/3).
Find \dfrac{d^{35}}{dx^{35}} (x\sin x)

Find constants A and B so that, for y = A\sin x + B\cos x, the following holds:
y'' + y' - 2y = \sin x
Hint: If y = A\sin x + B\cos x, then y' = A\cos x - B\sin x, and y'' = -A\sin x - B\cos x.
Find the points on the curve y = \dfrac{\cos x}{2 + \sin x} where the graph has a horizontal tangent.
Find the limit: \ds \lim_{x\to 0} \csc x\sin (\sin x)
Find the limit: \ds \lim_{x\to \pi/4} \dfrac{1-\tan x}{\sin x - \cos x}
